question_text.markdown:
Which one of the following statements for D.I. Mendeleeff, is incorrect?

(JEE Main, 22 Jul 2021)

options.text: He authored the textbook - Principles of Chemistry.
At the time he proposed Periodic Table of elements, structure of atom was known.
Element with atomic number 101 is named after him.

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2)**

Mendeleev proposed his periodic table in 1869. The structure of the atom was NOT known at that time (Thomson's model came in 1897). So statement (2) is incorrect.

- (1) Mendeleev authored 'Principles of Chemistry'.
- (3) Element 101 is Mendelevium (Md).
- (4) Mendeleev invented an accurate barometer.

question_text.markdown:
Which of the following material is **not** a semiconductor?

(JEE Main, 06 Apr 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Graphite**

Graphite is a conductor due to delocalized pi electrons. Si and Ge are semiconductors. CuO is a p-type semiconductor. Graphite is NOT a semiconductor.

question_text.markdown:
Identify the correct statements about p-block elements:

(A) Non-metals have higher electronegativity than metals.
(B) Non-metals have lower ionisation enthalpy than metals.
(C) Compounds formed between highly reactive nonmetals and highly reactive metals are generally ionic.
(D) The non-metal oxides are generally basic in nature.
(E) The metal oxides are generally acidic or neutral in nature.

(JEE Main, 08 Apr 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) A and C only**

- A: Non-metals have higher electronegativity than metals. (Correct)
- B: Non-metals have HIGHER IE than metals, not lower. (Wrong)
- C: Reactive metal + reactive non-metal gives ionic compound e.g. NaCl. (Correct)
- D: Non-metal oxides are ACIDIC (SO3, CO2), not basic. (Wrong)
- E: Metal oxides are BASIC (Na2O, CaO), not acidic. (Wrong)

question_text.markdown:
If IUPAC name of an element is "Unununnium" then the element belongs to $n$th group of periodic table. The value of $n$ is ____.

(JEE Main, 30 Jan 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: 11**

Un=1, Un=1, Un=1 gives Z = 111 (Roentgenium, Rg). Config: [Rn] 5f14 6d9 7s2. d-block element with 9 d + 2 s = 11 valence electrons. Group = 11 (like Cu, Ag, Au).

question_text.markdown:
Match List-I (Atomic number) with List-II (Block of periodic table):

**List-I:** (A) 37, (B) 78, (C) 52, (D) 65

**List-II:** I. p-block, II. d-block, III. f-block, IV. s-block

(JEE Main, 30 Jan 2023)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III**

- Z=37 (Rb): [Kr] 5s1 -> s-block (IV)
- Z=78 (Pt): [Xe] 4f14 5d9 6s1 -> d-block (II)
- Z=52 (Te): [Kr] 4d10 5s2 5p4 -> p-block (I)
- Z=65 (Tb): [Xe] 4f9 6s2 -> f-block (III)

question_text.markdown:
Element 'E' belongs to period 4 and group 16 of the periodic table. The valence shell electron configuration of the element which is just above 'E' in the group is:

(JEE Main, 28 Jun 2022)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3)**

Group 16, Period 4 -> E = Se (Z=34). Element just above Se in Group 16 = S (Z=16), Period 3. Valence config of S: 3s2 3p4.

question_text.markdown:
The atomic number of the element unnilennium is:

(JEE Main, 03 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (1) 109**

un=1, nil=0, enn=9 -> Z = 109 (Meitnerium, Mt). IUPAC roots: nil=0, un=1, bi=2, tri=3, quad=4, pent=5, hex=6, sept=7, oct=8, enn=9.

question_text.markdown:
The elements with atomic numbers 101 and 104 belong to, respectively:

(JEE Main, 04 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) Actinoids and Group 4**

- Z=101 (Md): [Rn] 5f13 7s2 -> 5f -> Actinoid
- Z=104 (Rf): [Rn] 5f14 6d2 7s2 -> 6d -> d-block, Group 4 (like Ti, Zr, Hf)

question_text.markdown:
The atomic number of Unnilunium is ____.

(JEE Main, 06 Sep 2020)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: 101**

Un=1, nil=0, un=1 -> Z = 101 (Mendelevium, Md). Config: [Rn] 5f13 7s2 -> Actinoid, named after Mendeleev.

question_text.markdown:
The IUPAC symbol for the element with atomic number 119 would be:

(JEE Main, 08 Apr 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Uue**

Z=119: 1->Un, 1->Un, 9->enn -> Symbol = Uue (Ununennium). Period 8, Group 1 (alkali metal).

question_text.markdown:
The group number, number of valence electrons, and valency of an element with atomic number 15, respectively, are:

(JEE Main, 12 Apr 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) 15, 5 and 3**

Z=15 = Phosphorus: [Ne] 3s2 3p3. Group 15, valence electrons = 5 (3s2+3p3), valency = 3 (forms PCl3, needs 3 more electrons).

question_text.markdown:
The element with $Z = 120$ (not yet discovered) will be a/an:

(JEE Main, 12 Jan 2019)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (2) alkaline earth metal**

Z=120: [Og] 8s2 -> last electron in 8s -> s-block, Group 2 -> alkaline earth metal. (Z=119 would be Group 1 alkali metal.)

question_text.markdown:
The correct order of the first ionization enthalpy is:

(JEE Main, 04 Apr 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) B > Al > Ga**

Group 13 IE1 (kJ/mol): B=800, Al=577, Ga=579. Ga is slightly higher than Al due to poor shielding by 3d electrons (anomaly), but B is always highest. Among the options, B > Al > Ga is the correct partial ordering.

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** The correct order of first ionization enthalpy of Li, Na, F and Cl is Na < Li < Cl < F.

**Statement II:** The correct order of negative electron gain enthalpy of Li, Na, F and Cl is Na < Li < F < Cl.

(JEE Main, 04 Apr 2024)

options.text: Statement I is true but Statement II is false
Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Both Statement I and Statement II are false
Both Statement I and Statement II are true

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Both true**

IE1: Na(496) < Li(520) < Cl(1251) < F(1681) kJ/mol. Correct.

EGE magnitude: Na(53) < Li(60) < F(328) < Cl(349) kJ/mol. Correct. Cl has more negative EGE than F because F's compact 2p orbitals cause electron repulsion when extra electron is added.

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** The metallic radius of Na is 1.86 A and the ionic radius of Na+ is lesser than 1.86 A.

**Statement II:** Ions are always smaller in size than the corresponding elements.

(JEE Main, 05 Apr 2024)

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are false
Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is true
Both Statement I and Statement II are true
Statement I is correct but Statement II is false

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4)**

St. I: Na+ (1.02 A) < Na (1.86 A). Cations are smaller than parent atom. Correct.

St. II: Anions are LARGER than parent atoms (e.g., Cl- = 1.81 A > Cl = 0.99 A). So 'ions are always smaller' is false. Only cations are smaller; anions are larger.

question_text.markdown:
Match List I with List II:

| List-I (Elements) | List-II (Properties in their groups) |
|---|---|
| A. Cl, S | I. Highest electronegativity |
| B. Ge, As | II. Largest atomic size |
| C. Fr, Ra | III. Properties of both metals and non-metals |
| D. F, O | IV. Highest negative electron gain enthalpy |

(JEE Main, 08 Apr 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I**

A (Cl, S): Highest negative EGE in their groups (IV). Anomaly: Cl > F and S > O in EGE.
B (Ge, As): Metalloids - show properties of both metals and non-metals (III).
C (Fr, Ra): Heaviest in their groups -> largest atomic size (II).
D (F, O): Most electronegative in their groups (I).

question_text.markdown:
The element having the highest first ionization enthalpy among Si, Al, N and C is:

(JEE Main, 29 Jan 2024)

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) N**

IE1 (kJ/mol): Al(577) < Si(786) < C(1086) < N(1402). N has half-filled 2p3 configuration which has extra stability due to exchange energy. Hence N has the highest IE1 among these four elements.

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** Fluorine has most negative electron gain enthalpy in its group.

**Statement II:** Oxygen has least negative electron gain enthalpy in its group.

(JEE Main, 29 Jan 2024)

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are true
Statement I is true but Statement II is false
Both Statement I and Statement II are false
Statement I is false but Statement II is true

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) St. I false, St. II true**

St. I is FALSE: In Group 17, Cl (-349 kJ/mol) has more negative EGE than F (-328 kJ/mol). F's compact 2p orbitals cause electron-electron repulsion when extra electron is added.

St. II is TRUE: In Group 16, O (-141 kJ/mol) has the least negative EGE. Order: S(-200) > Se(-195) > Te(-190) > O(-141). Same reason - O's small size causes repulsion.

question_text.markdown:
Given below are two statements:

**Statement I:** Along the period, the chemical reactivity of the element gradually increases from group 1 to group 18.

**Statement II:** The nature of oxides formed by group 1 element is basic while that of group 17 elements is acidic.

(JEE Main, 30 Jan 2024)

options.text: Both Statement I and Statement II are true.
Statement I is true but Statement II is False.
Statement I is false but Statement II is true.
Both Statement I and Statement II are false.

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (3) St. I false, St. II true**

St. I is FALSE: Reactivity does NOT gradually increase from Group 1 to 18. Noble gases (Group 18) are least reactive. Reactivity is highest at extremes (Groups 1 and 17) and lowest at Group 18.

St. II is TRUE: Group 1 oxides (Na2O, K2O) are basic. Group 17 oxides (Cl2O7, Cl2O) are acidic.

question_text.markdown:
In case of isoelectronic species the size of F-, Ne and Na+ is affected by:

(JEE Main, 01 Feb 2024)

options.text: None of the factors because their size is the same
Electron-electron interaction in the outer orbitals

solution.text_markdown:
**Answer: (4) Nuclear charge (Z)**

F-, Ne, Na+ are isoelectronic - all have 10 electrons (1s2 2s2 2p6). Same n, same electron count. The only variable is nuclear charge Z: F-(Z=9) > Ne(Z=10) > Na+(Z=11) in size. Higher Z means stronger pull on the same electrons, giving smaller size.
